<img src="https:/ /blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEiqTosaeIs4AMYukkmgUBEii6iQcrr9_dNKM0cHnW6m9Wi8yX0V-QCduQfkqLyQPNpVbze3OFO-nPG5Wm9DLMM8pEAfhQGq-TEJroLJGQyqNr-hlJNkToBC mgJbphrCRvlv95gkDQH0ScT7VrXu2VCTKyiWy8yYM4G8voF0kD0K2oxwg2M2xBcz1yQnU0Zb/s600/USP.gif" style="显示：无；" />; <p>; 大型语言模型 (LLM) 的最新进展非常有前途，这反映在它们在<em>;少样本</em>;和<em>;零样本</em>;设置中解决一般问题的能力，即使没有对这些任务进行明确的培训。这是令人印象深刻的，因为在几次镜头设置中，法学硕士在给出测试问题之前只看到了一些问答演示。更具挑战性的是零样本设置，其中仅通过测试问题直接提示法学硕士。 </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <p>; 尽管少数镜头设置极大地减少了针对特定用例调整模型所需的数据量，但仍然存在以下情况：生成示例提示可能具有挑战性。例如，为通用模型涵盖的广泛任务手工制作少量演示可能很困难，或者对于看不见的任务来说是不可能的。例如，对于长文章摘要或需要领域知识的任务（例如医学问答），生成示例答案可能具有挑战性。在这种情况下，具有高零样本性能的模型非常有用，因为不需要手动生成提示。然而，零样本性能通常较弱，因为法学硕士没有提供指导，因此容易出现虚假输出。 </p>; <p>; 在“<a href="https://aclanthology.org/2023.findings-acl.216/">;通过自适应提示进行更好的零样本推理</a>;”中，发表于<a href="https://2023.aclweb.org/">;ACL 2023</a>;，我们提出基于一致性的自适应提示 (COSP) </em>;来解决这一困境。 COSP 是一种用于推理问题的零样本自动提示方法，仅使用未标记的样本（通常很容易获得）和模型自己的预测来仔细选择和构建 LLM 的伪演示。通过 COSP，我们在很大程度上缩小了零样本和少样本之间的性能差距，同时保留了零样本提示的理想通用性。我们遵循“<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.14926">;通用自适应提示</a>;”(USP)，已在 <a href="https://2023 接受。 emnlp.org/">;EMNLP 2023</a>;，其中我们将这一想法扩展到广泛的<em>;通用自然语言理解（NLU）和自然语言生成（NLG）任务中，并展示了其有效性。 </p>; <br />; <h2>;用自己的输出提示法学硕士</h2>; <p>;知道法学硕士受益于演示并至少具有<em>;一些</em>;零样本能力，我们想知道是否该模型的零样本输出可以作为模型自我提示的演示。挑战在于零样本解决方案是不完美的，我们冒着给法学硕士提供低质量演示的风险，这可能比根本没有演示更糟糕。确实，下图表明，在问题中添加正确的演示可以导致测试题的正确答案（演示 1 带问题），而添加不正确的演示（演示 2 + 问题，演示 3 带问题）会导致错误答案。因此，我们需要选择可靠的自生成演示。 </p>; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="1051" data-original-width="776" 高度=“640”src =“https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi5QShw0e9OdtzA9Ob5vAtWloPZGIZgCGFSL9okO-5pxIN3M2QciE1MOT73NsdaHwOz5LiH94IZRkE0SYSJ2fiiBSNR_qHCrO-URHqZP q7Fhhpvm6wtykLsySfF9l5ERsbOqtT_J1-A8pjoOa9htdvXEnL4-WRbP-Kn85aIz7G-BvWNflcaG4lUPomVlLU8/w472-h640/image6.png"宽度="472" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;<em style="text-align: left;">;示例输入&推理任务的输出，这说明需要精心设计上下文演示的选择过程（<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1608.01413">;MultiArith</a>; 数据集  <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2204.02311">;PaLM-62B</a>; 型号）：(1) 零射击</em>;<a href="https:// blog.research.google/2022/05/language-models-perform-reasoning-via.html" style="text-align: left;">;思想链</a>;<em style="text-align : left;">; 没有演示：逻辑正确但答案错误； （2）正确演示（Demo1）及正确答案； （3）正确但重复的演示（Demo2）导致重复的输出； （4）错误的演示（Demo3）导致答案错误；但是 (5) 再次组合 Demo3 和 Demo1 会得到正确的答案。</em>;</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <p>; COSP 利用了 LLM 的一个关键观察结果：自信且一致的预测更有可能是正确的。当然，这一观察结果取决于法学硕士的不确定性估计有多好。幸运的是，在大型模型中，<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2207.05221">;之前的</a>; <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2210.11610">;可以工作</ a>;表明不确定性估计是稳健的。由于测量置信度仅需要模型预测，而不需要标签，因此我们建议将其用作正确性的零样本代理。然后将高置信度输出及其输入用作<em>;伪</em>;演示。 </p>; <p>;以此为出发点，我们根据模型的<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2203.11171">;自我一致性</a>;来估计模型对其输出的置信度。并使用此措施来选择强大的自生成演示。我们以零样本方式多次向法学硕士询问同一问题<a href="https://blog.research.google/2022/05/language-models-perform-reasoning-via.html">;思维链< /a>; (CoT) 提示。为了引导模型生成一系列可能的理由和最终答案，我们引入了由“温度”超参数控制的随机性。在极端情况下，如果模型 100% 确定，它每次都应该输出相同的最终答案。然后，我们计算答案的熵来衡量不确定性——具有高度自洽性且法学硕士更确定的答案可能是正确的并会被选择。 </p>; <p>; 假设我们面临一组未标记的问题，则 COSP 方法为： </p>; <ol>; <li>;将每个未标记的问题输入到 LLM 中，通过对模型进行多次采样，获得多个基本原理和答案。最常见的答案会突出显示，然后是衡量多个采样输出答案一致性的分数（越高越好）。除了支持更一致的答案之外，我们还惩罚回答中的重复（即重复的单词或短语），并鼓励所选演示的多样性。我们以评分函数的形式编码对一致、不重复和多样化输出的偏好，该评分函数由三个分数的加权和组成，用于选择自我生成的伪演示。</li>; <li>;我们串联将伪演示转化为测试题，将其提供给LLM，并获得最终的预测答案。</li>; </ol>; <tablealign="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr -caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https:// blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEidn_WHASrzLG7rsqvKr5XqTi0VE0hEonQJsCRy0XHnM_DsWP4u1izMPUvfakpLd9FJvu47XXspD3vgIXrnrEhbrGR5vxSkcRRtbrU7HwHh6zLpywepMg3 9GUAW6uSVYxW-JzdOl5IVt9KPqLDVVCvjz86e6vQgZK79FKAF5wGdpztohbWhe7tVtVwcNBgh/s949/image4.png" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-高度=“396”数据原始宽度=“949”src=“https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEidn_WHASrzLG7rsqvKr5XqTi0VE0hEonQJsCRy0XHnM_DsWP4u1izMPUvfakpLd9FJvu47XXspD3vgIXrnrEhbr GR5vxSkcRRtbrU7HwHh6zLpywepMg39GUAW6uSVYxW-JzdOl5IVt9KPqLDVVCvjz86e6vQgZK79FKAF5wGdpztohbWhe7tVtVwcNBgh/s16000/image4.png"/>;</a>;< /td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;<em style="text-align: left;">;COSP 说明：第一阶段（<strong>;左</strong>;），我们多次运行零样本 CoT 来生成一组演示（每个演示由问题、生成的基本原理和预测组成）并分配分数。在第 2 阶段（<strong>;右</strong>;），我们用伪演示（蓝色框）增强当前的测试问题，并再次查询 LLM。对两个阶段输出的多数投票形成最终预测。</em>;</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <p>; COSP 侧重于 CoT 提示的问答任务由于问题有唯一的正确答案，因此很容易衡量自我一致性。但这对于其他任务来说可能很困难，例如开放式问答或没有唯一答案的生成任务（例如文本摘要）。为了解决这个限制，我们引入了 USP，其中我们将我们的方法推广到其他一般 NLP 任务：</p>; <ul>; <li>;<em>;分类</em>; (CLS)：我们可以计算以下概率的问题每个类别使用每个类别的神经网络输出 logits。这样，我们就可以通过计算 logit 分布的熵来测量不确定性，而无需多次采样。</li>; <li>;<em>;简式生成</em>;（SFG）：我们可以解决诸如问答之类的问题使用与上述 COSP 相同的过程，但如有必要，无需基本原理生成步骤。</li>; <li>;<em>;长格式生成</em>; (LFG)：<em>; </em>;像摘要和翻译这样的问题，问题通常是开放式的，即使 LLM 是确定的，输出也不太可能相同。在本例中，我们使用<em>;重叠度量</em>;来计算<em>;成对</em>;的平均值<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ROUGE_ (metric)">;同一查询的不同输出之间的 ROUGE 分数</a>;。</li>; </ul>; <tablealign="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-标题容器" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger .googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjn2mgVNUmsKVPYKo3zrcQnq3nHT0xIzCk2rIOK0fSrFIOEkyCrx7MWNnTrOdwnFRlGbid1cj8OqV2xBCfOtgv5oiuUPoQjRY9CpMnjM79P0mQmoyQqluMPZs qFQUtS7AtPy5Uw-sf5UT_dV_bRbGWSRQiR5U2tDIYd2zxsk_lboJsKG4mcBZKxp5gEeT_T/s1360/image3.gif" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height =“640”数据原始宽度=“1360”src=“https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjn2mgVNUmsKVPYKo3zrcQnq3nHT0xIzCk2rIOK0fSrFIOEkyCrx7MWNnTrOdwnFRlGbid1cj8OqV2xBCfOtgv5oi uUPoQjRY9CpMnjM79P0mQmoyQqluMPZsqFQUtS7AtPy5Uw-sf5UT_dV_bRbGWSRQiR5U2tDIYd2zxsk_lboJsKG4mcBZKxp5gEeT_T/s16000/image3.gif"/>;</a>;</ td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;<em style="text-align: left;">;示例性任务中的 USP 说明（分类、QA 和文本摘要）。与 COSP 类似，LLM 首先对未标记的数据集生成预测，该数据集的输出根据任务类型使用 logit 熵、一致性或对齐进行评分，并从这些输入输出对中选择伪演示。在第 2 阶段，测试实例通过伪演示进行了增强以进行预测。</em>;</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <p>; 我们计算相关置信度分数，具体取决于关于上述一组未标记测试样本的任务类型。评分后，与 COSP 类似，我们选择自信的、多样化的、重复性较低的答案，形成模型生成的伪演示集。最后，我们通过这些伪演示以几次镜头的形式再次查询 LLM，以获得整个测试集的最终预测。 </p>; <br />; <h2>;关键结果</h2>; <p>; 对于 COSP，我们专注于一组六个算术和常识推理问题，并与 0-shot-CoT 进行比较（即“< a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2205.11916">;让我们一步一步思考</a>;“而已）。我们在所有基线中使用自一致性，以便它们使用与 COSP 大致相同数量的计算资源。与三个法学硕士相比，我们发现零样本 COSP 显着优于标准零样本基线。 </p>; </table>; <br />; <h2>;结论</h2>; <p>; 零样本推理是现代法学硕士备受追捧的一项能力，但其成功却带来了独特的挑战。我们提出 COSP 和 USP，这是一系列适用于各种任务的多功能、零样本自动提示技术。我们在众多任务和模型组合中展示了比最先进基线的巨大改进。 </p>; <br />; <h2>;致谢</h2>; <p>; <em>;这项工作由 Xingchen Wan、Ruoxi Sun、Hootan Nakhost、Hanjun Dai、Julian Martin Eisenschlos、Sercan Ö 进行。阿里克和托马斯·普菲斯特。我们要感谢 Jinsung Yoon Xuzhi Wang 提供的有用评论，以及 Google Cloud AI Research 的其他同事的讨论和反馈。</em>; <category schema="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Machine Learning">;</category>;<title type="text">;MetNet-3：现状Google 产品中提供的艺术神经天气模型</stitle>;<content type="html">;<span class="byline-author">;发布者：Google Research 的 Samier Merchant 和 Google DeepMind 的 Nal Kalchbrenner</span>; <img src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhdgnhML03N9vxEdGH1TkBATtxGpjyO5XYgZwJY5dY0-sPIAvrmCll4J8I9owyJTNOHZdq6MMZskWsYJDZivZA_zvj2atWhUsPoxWnNyifi FAm83GC2EsZ4xgre8bCk32Yzv3vlR4pGn12H7T5Vkbz5BaErZ22JRB-OqveQ7EDHsrCYjKN65Soc1FrZNwvu/s1600/metnethero1.gif" style="显示：无；" />; <p>; 预测降水、温度和风等天气变量对于社会的许多方面（从日常规划和交通到能源生产）至关重要。随着我们不断看到更多的洪水、干旱和热浪等极端天气事件，准确的预报对于准备和减轻其影响至关重要。未来的前 24 小时尤其重要，因为它们具有高度可预测性和可操作性，可以帮助人们及时做出明智的决策并保证安全。 </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <p>; 今天我们推出了一个名为 <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2306.06079">;MetNet-3</ a>;，由 Google Research 和 Google DeepMind 开发。基于早期的 <a href="https://blog.research.google/2020/03/a-neural-weather-model-for-eight-hour.html?m=1">;MetNet</a>; 和<a href="https://blog.research.google/2021/11/metnet-2-deep-learning-for-12-hour.html">;MetNet-2</a>; 模型，MetNet-3 提供了高对更多核心变量（包括降水、表面温度、风速和风向以及露点）进行长达 24 小时的分辨率预测。 MetNet-3 创建时间上平滑且高度精细的预测，提前时间间隔为 2 分钟，空间分辨率为 1 至 4 公里。与传统方法相比，MetNet-3 实现了强大的性能，优于基于物理的最佳单成员和多成员<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Numerical_weather_prediction">;数值天气预报</a>; (NWP) 模型 - 例如<a href="https://rapidrefresh.noaa.gov/hrrr/">;高分辨率快速刷新</a>; (HRRR) 和<a href="https://www. ecmwf.int/en/forecasts/documentation-and-support/medium-range-forecasts#:~:text=ENS%20is%20a%20probabilistic%20forecast,high%20winds%20or%20heavy%20rain)。">;集合预报suite</a>; (ENS) — 适用于多个区域，最多可提前 24 小时。 </p>; <p>; 最后，我们在各种 Google <a href="https://support.google.com/websearch/answer/13692898">;产品和技术</a>;中集成了 MetNet-3 的功能，其中天气相关。 MetNet-3 目前在美国本土和欧洲部分地区推出，重点是 12 小时降水预报，正在帮助为多个国家和语言的人们提供准确可靠的天气信息。 </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;稀疏观测值的致密化</h2>; <p >; 许多最近的机器学习天气模型使用传统方法生成的大气状态（例如，来自 NWP 的数据同化）作为建立预报的主要起点。相比之下，MetNet 模型的一个定义特征是使用对大气的直接观测直接观测的优点是保真度和分辨率较高，但直接观测来自不同高度的各种传感器，包括地面气象站和轨道卫星，具有不同程度的稀疏性。例如，通过 <a href="https://mrms.nssl.noaa.gov/">;NOAA 的多雷达/多传感器系统</a>;等雷达得出的降水量估算（ MRMS）是相对密集的图像，而位于地面、提供温度和风等变量测量值的气象站只是分布在某个区域的点。 </p>; <p>; 除了之前 MetNet 模型中使用的数据源之外，MetNet-3 还包括气象站的点测量作为输入和目标，目的是在所有位置进行预测。为此，MetNet-3 的关键创新是一种称为致密化的技术，它将基于物理的模型中传统的数据同化和模拟两步过程合并到神经网络的单次传递中。致密化的主要组成部分如下所示。尽管致密化技术单独适用于特定的数据流，但由此产生的致密化预测受益于进入 MetNet-3 的所有其他输入流，包括地形、卫星、雷达和 NWP 分析功能。 MetNet-3 的默认输入中不包含 NWP 预报。 </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>; <tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEie1m1p0i-MWhS7Ih5RGzV-AQuDDPwgao4SpmnSUTdSsy7fcEwk4Soj5IJ8FqtGjhvi4ot2HKZdaQh3Hpu4CviRsx7 FujT_4bbvpV8mu15Zt5bO5KbMGaaqIZoAGUp77ltVYH-zt2HTwVxbuGZHJt-0lbXZT-ukJH_KtB3pnHdRrRpZ2r5WgMSNGXnu-H8j /s1929/image22.gif" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="1929" data-original-width="1600" src =“https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEie1m1p0i-MWhS7Ih5RGzV-AQuDDPwgao4SpmnSUTdSsy7fcEwk4Soj5IJ8FqtGjhvi4ot2HKZdaQh3Hpu4CviRsx7FujT_4bbvpV8mu15Zt5b O5KbMGaaqIZoAGUp77ltVYH-zt2HTwVxbuGZHJt-0lbXZT-ukJH_KtB3pnHdRrRpZ2r5WgMSNGXnu-H8j/s16000/image22.gif"/>;</a>;</td>;</ tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;<b>;A</b>;) 在训练期间，一小部分气象站从输入中被屏蔽，而保持在目标中。 <b>;B</b>;）为了评估对未训练位置的泛化，一组由正方形表示的气象站从不用于训练，仅用于评估。 <b>;C</b>;) 在评估过程中包含来自这些覆盖范围稀疏的气象站的数据，以确定这些区域的预测质量。 <b>;D</b>;) 最终预报使用全套训练气象站作为输入，并在空间参数共享的辅助下生成全密集预报。</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; < div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;空间和时间高分辨率</h2>; <p>; 使用直接观测的核心优势是其高空间和时间分辨率解决。例如，气象站和地面雷达站分别以 1 公里的分辨率每隔几分钟在特定点提供测量结果；这与最先进模型的同化状态形成鲜明对比 <a href="https://www.ecmwf.int/en/forecasts/documentation-and-support/medium-range-forecasts# :~:text=ENS%20is%20a%20probabilistic%20forecast,high%20winds%20or%20heavy%20rain).">;ENS</a>;，每 6 小时生成一次，分辨率为 9 公里，每小时生成一次小时预测。为了处理如此高分辨率，MetNet-3 保留了该系列模型的另一个定义特征，即提前期调节。以分钟为单位的预测提前时间直接作为神经网络的输入给出。这使得 MetNet-3 能够有效地对短至 2 分钟的时间间隔内的观测的高时间频率进行建模。致密化与前置时间调节和高分辨率直接观测相结合，可生成完全密集的 24 小时预测，时间分辨率为 2 分钟，同时仅从 <a href="https://madis.ncep.noaa.gov 中的 1,000 个点进行学习/madis_OMO.shtml">;一分钟观测</a>; (OMO) 气象站网络遍布美国各地。 </p>; <p>; MetNet-3 预测每个输出变量和每个位置的边际多项式概率分布，提供超出平均值的丰富信息。这使我们能够将 MetNet-3 的概率输出与高级概率集合 NWP 模型的输出进行比较，包括来自<a href="https://www.ecmwf.int/">;欧洲中等中心的集合预测 ENS -范围天气预报</a>;和来自<a href=的<a href="https://www.spc.noaa.gov/exper/href/">;高分辨率集合预报</a>; (HREF) “https://www.noaa.gov/">;美国国家海洋和大气管理局</a>;。由于两个模型输出的概率性质，我们能够计算诸如 <a href="https://confluence.ecmwf.int/display/FUG/Section+12.B+Statistical+Concepts+- +Probabilistic+Data#:~:text=%20连续%20排名%20概率%20分数，%20预测%20%20完全%20不准确。">;连续排名概率分数</a>; (CRPS)。下图突出显示了致密化结果，并说明 MetNet 的预测不仅具有更高的分辨率，而且在重叠交付周期进行评估时也更加准确。 </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>; <tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEiJsf6Y6gV9VjK_rS_Bf_WLWdsJOq3sQbdaW26VSp2vX1Fq5j7VcWl4VDi3BeBFpEcH_YGrkU9ozJyuP5dh 8tWWCU4yGzlmGBTfwM-kXGKZvdvI1DF17V4kSJSGGBIacqaCO4N1Oc8P4PymPWdglJbew_cjP9reFSJuHR3_ikZfZFuzN6aC8F17TAtiJPIg/s768/image44.gif"样式="左边距：自动；右边距：自动；">;<img border="0" data-original-height="768" data-original-width="600" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent. com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEiJsf6Y6gV9VjK_rS_Bf_WLWdsJOq3sQbdaW26VSp2vX1Fq5j7VcWl4VDi3BeBFpEcH_YGrkU9ozJyuP5dh8tWWCU4yGzlmGBTfwM-kXGKZvdvi1DF1 7V4kSJSGGBIacqaCO4N1Oc8P4PymPWdglJbew_cjP9reFSJuHR3_ikZfZFuzN6aC8F17TAtiJPIg/s16000/image44.gif" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align : center;">;<b>;顶部</b>;：MetNet-3 对未来 24 小时内每 2 分钟的风速预测，空间分辨率为 4 公里。 <b>;底部</b>;：ENS 每小时预报，空间分辨率为 18 公里。 <br />;这两种不同的空间结构主要是由科罗拉多山脉的存在驱动的。较暗对应于较高的风速。更多示例请参见：<a href="https://youtube.com/watch?v=iB1DzHNqH_o">;1</a>;、<a href="https://youtube.com/watch?v=LlWB558jKJk" >;2</a>;、<a href="https://youtube.com/watch?v=74bFo3nkbe4">;3</a>;、<a href="https://youtube.com/watch?v= MKUzYQZn9sQ">;4</a>;.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <tablealign="center"cellpadding="0"cellpacing="0"class="tr-caption-container " style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent. com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhBhlSum7x274E9KQGzLnjM9iXNEhifOJjKzt1Cwa5YyABCbaB68Mkr3gFvIVU连字符IGOqUE78MqGTK992NK8zrdKrqKxtFlYf1qeWYNkTa4PVzD3u_9 lmQAjKnbLILHAkPhIOCvyAI6qBtfyf-z_xgUys3gXRJd_GSs3-qnyq0yFbjvmxdXAbVldV-xrIRJ/s1120/image11.png" imageanchor="1" style="margin-left: auto; <p>; 与气象站变量相比，降水估计更加密集，因为它们来自地面雷达。 MetNet-3 的降水建模与 MetNet-1 和 2 类似，但将 1 公里空间粒度的高分辨率降水预报扩展到与其他变量相同的 24 小时提前时间，如下面的动画所示。在整个 24 小时范围内，MetNet-3 在降水方面的性能实现了比 ENS 更好的 CRPS 值。 </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; <div style="line -height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;提供实时机器学习预测</h2>; <p>; 根据历史数据训练和评估像 MetNet-3 这样的天气预报模型只是其中的一部分向用户提供基于 ML 的预测的过程。开发用于天气预报的实时ML系统时，有很多考虑因素，例如从多个不同的来源摄入实时输入数据，运行推理，实现对输出的实时验证，从模型的丰富输出中建立见解，导致直观的用户体验，并在Google规模上服务结果 - 全部连续周期，每隔几分钟刷新一次。 </p>; <p>;我们开发了一种实时系统，能够在整个连续美国和欧洲27个国家/地区的27个国家/地区的降水预测，最多12个小时。 </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>; </td>; </tr>; </tbody>; </table>; <p>;生成降水预测的过程的例证它使用了近乎连续的推断，该推断允许模型不断基于传入的数据流创建完整的预测。这种推论方式与传统推理系统不同，并且由于传入数据的不同特征是必要的。该模型将各种数据源作为输入，例如雷达，卫星和数值天气预测。这些输入中的每一个都有不同的刷新频率以及空间和时间分辨率。一些数据源（例如天气观察和雷达）具有类似于连续数据流的特征，而其他数据源（例如NWP同化）类似于数据批次。该系统能够在空间和时间上对所有这些数据源对齐，从而使模型能够以非常高的节奏对接下来的12个小时的降水进行更新的了解。 </p>; <p>;在上述过程中，该模型能够预测任意的离散概率分布。我们开发了新颖的技术，将这个密集的输出空间转变为用户友好的信息，这些信息可以在整个Google产品和技术中获得丰富的体验。 </p>; <div style =“ line-height：40％;”>; <br />; </>; </>; </>;提供有关天气的有用，及时和准确的信息。这些信息用于多种目的，例如计划户外活动，旅行包装以及在恶劣天气活动中保持安全。 </p>; <p>; Metnet-3的最新准确性，高时空和空间分辨率以及概率的性质使得创建独特的超本地天气见解成为可能。对于连续的美国和欧洲，Metnet-3正在运行，并产生实时的12小时降水预测，这些预测现在已在Google <a href="https://support.google.com/websearch/answer/13692898">;上进行。产品和技术</a>;天气相关的地方，例如搜索。该模型的丰富输出被合成为可行的信息，并立即提供给数百万用户。 </p>; <p>;例如，从其移动设备中搜索天气信息的用户将收到高度局部的降水预测数据，包括根据产品的时间表图表图，并取决于产品。 </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>; metnet-3在Android上的Google App上天气中的降水量输出（<b>;左</b>;）和移动Web搜索（<b>;右<b>;右< /b>;）。</td>; </tr>; </tbody>; </table>; <div style =“ line-height：40％;”>; <br />; </>; </div>; <h2>;结论</h2 >; <p>; Metnet-3是一种用于天气预报的新的深度学习模型，该模型优于最先进的物理模型，用于24小时预测的核心天气变量。它有可能为天气预报创造新的可能性，并提高许多活动的安全性和效率，例如运输，农业和能源生产。 Metnet-3是运营的，其预测是在与天气相关的几种Google产品中提供的。 </p>; Audioplethysmography（APG）使ANC可听物可以监视用户的生理信号，例如心率和心率变异性，而无需添加额外的传感器或损害电池寿命。 APG exhibits high resilience to motion artifacts, adheres to <a href="https://www.health.belgium.be/sites/default/files/uploads/fields/fpshealth_theme_file/19099349/Canadian%20guidelines%20for%20ultrasound.pdf “>;安全法规</a>;低于极限的80 dB边缘，仍然不受密封条件的影响，并且包括所有肤色。 </p>; <p>; <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/wiki/ear_canal">;听觉运河</a>;从<a a href =“ en.wikipedia.org/wiki/deep_auricular_artery">; arteria auricularis profunda </a>;，也称为深耳动脉。该动脉形成了一个复杂的较小血管的网络，可广泛渗透到听觉运河。由心跳引起的血管形状的略有变化（和<a href="https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/8834671">;血压</a>;）可能导致体积和体积的微妙变化耳道的压力使耳道成为健康感应的理想位置。 </p>; <p>;最近的研究已经通过将众多传感器包装在一起使用可听物来进行健康传感探索 - 例如，<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/wiki/photoplethysmogramcommogramcommpograms </a photoplethyMograms </a >; (PPG) and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrocardiography">;electrocardiograms</a>; (ECG) — with a microcontroller to enable health applications, such as sleep monitoring, heart rate and血压跟踪。但是，这种传感器安装范式不可避免地增加了成本，重量，功耗，声学设计的复杂性以及对可听物品的挑战，从而构成了广泛采用的强烈障碍。 </p>; <p>;现有的ANC听证物部署反馈和馈电麦克风来浏览ANC功能。这些麦克风创建<a href="https://dl.acm.org/doi/abs/10.1145/3550314">;新机会</a>;用于各种感应应用耳道。例如，反馈麦克风可用于聆听心跳，而前馈麦克风可以听到呼吸。 <a href="https://dl.acm.org/doi/abs/10.1145/345864.3467680">;学术研究</a>;关于这种被动感应范式呼吸监测和身体活动识别。但是，消费级ANC耳机中的麦克风带有<a href="https://research.google/pubs/pubs/pub52579/">; inden-in High-pass filters </a>;以防止身体运动或强风中的饱和噪音。耳道中被动聆听的信号质量也很大程度上依赖于耳塞密封条件。因此，嵌入依赖于商用ANC耳机的低频信号（≤50Hz）的健康功能的健康特征是具有挑战性的。 </p>; <div style =“线路高：40％;”>; <br />; </>; </>; </div>; <h2>;测量微小的生理信号</h2>; <p>;标准基准测量了重要的产品质量的方法，并且它们存在于许多领域。一些标准的基准测量安全性：例如，当汽车制造商吹捧“五星级总体安全评级”时，他们是引用基准的。机器学习（ML）和AI Technologies中已经存在标准基准测试：例如，<a href="https://mlcommons.org/en/"/">; mlCommons </a>;协会操作<a href =“ https：https：https：https： //mlcommons.org/en/news/mlperf-inferef-indorage--q323/">; mlperf </a>;基准测试，这些基准测量了尖端AI硬件（例如Google tpus）的速度。但是，尽管在<a href="https://blog.google/technology/ai/our-responsible-apphach-to-building-guardrails-for-generative-generative-ai/">; ai安全< /a>;，目前尚无类似的AI安全标准基准。 </p>; <a name='more'>; </a>; <p>;我们很高兴支持非营利MLCommons协会的新努力，以开发标准的AI安全基准。开发有效和值得信赖的基准将需要提高AI安全测试技术并融合广泛的观点。 MLCommons的努力旨在将各个学术界和行业的专家研究人员聚集在一起，以开发标准的基准测试，以将AI系统的安全性衡量为每个人都能理解的分数。我们鼓励整个社区，从AI研究人员到政策专家，再到<a href="https://mlcommons.org/ai-safety">;加入我们</a>; </a>;为这项工作做出了贡献。 </p>; <div style =“线路高：40％;”>; <br>; </div>; <h2>;为什么AI安全基准？</h2>; <p>;像大多数先进的技术一样，AI有潜力巨大的好处，但也可能导致负面的结果，而没有适当的照顾。例如，人工智能技术可以在各种活动中提高人类生产力（例如，<a href =“ https://blog.google/technology/health/health/how-ai-can-can-improve-health-health-for-every-everyone-everyone-everyone-everyone-everywhere Where /“>;改善健康诊断</a>;和研究疾病研究，分析<a href="https://blog.google/outreach-initiatives/sustainability/google-google-transportation-eenergy-emissions-emissions-reduction- /a>;，以及更多）。但是，如果没有足够的预防措施，AI也可以用来支持有害或恶意活动，并以有偏见或进攻的方式做出反应。 </p>; <p>;通过提供跨类别的标准安全措施，例如有害使用，副本响应，AI控制风险等，标准的AI安全基准可以帮助社会获得AI的好处，同时确保该公司的利益正在采取足够的预防措施来减轻这些风险。最初，新生的安全基准可以帮助推动AI安全研究并为负责任的AI开发提供信息。随着时间和成熟，他们可以帮助用户和购买者了解AI系统。最终，它们可能是政策制定者的宝贵工具。 </p>; <p>;在计算机硬件中，基准（例如，<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/wiki/standard_performance_evaluation_corporation ">; spec </a>;，<a href =“ href =” en.wikipedia.org/wiki/transaction_processing_performance_council ">; tpc </a>;）表现出惊人的能力，可以在整个行业中保持研究，工程甚至在整个行业中的营销，以追求进步，我们相信标准AI安全基准可以帮助您做到帮助。在这个重要区域相同。 </p>; <div style =“线路高：40％;”>; <br>; </div>; <h2>;什么是标准AI安全基准？</h2>; <p>;学术和企业研究工作已经进行了实验一系列AI安全测试（例如，<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2009.11462">; realtoxicityprompts </a>;，<a href =“ 11/17/helm.html“>; stanford helm </a>;公平，偏见，毒性测量和<a href =” https://blog.google/technology/technology/ai/our-responsible-to-bucecnible-responsible-to-to-bucible-to-buachace--building--building--building--building--building- GuardRails-for-for-for-for-for-enerative-ai/“>; Google的Google Guardrails for Generative Ai </a>;）。但是，这些测试中的大多数都集中在为AI系统提供提示，并算法对输出进行评分，这是一个有用的开始，但仅限于测试提示的范围。此外，他们通常将开放数据集用于提示和响应，这些提示和响应可能已经（通常是无意）纳入了培训数据中。 </p>; <p>; MLCommons提出了一个多利益相关者的过程，用于选择测试并将其分组为子集，以衡量特定AI用例的安全性，并将这些测试的高度技术结果转化为每个人都可以理解的分数。 MLCommons提议创建一个平台，将这些现有测试融合到一个地方，并鼓励创建更严格的测试，从而推动前进的状态。用户将能够通过在线测试中访问这些测试，他们可以在其中使用引擎进行私人测试来生成和查看分数和离线测试。 </p>; <div style =“线路高：40％;”>; <br>; </div>; <h2>; AI安全基准应该是集体努力</h2>; <p>;负责的AI开发人员使用多样化的范围安全措施，包括自动测试，手动测试，红色小组（人类测试人员试图产生对抗性结果），软件施加的限制，数据和模型最佳实践以及审计。但是，确定已经采取了足够的预防措施可能具有挑战性，尤其是随着提供AI系统的公司社区的增长和多元化。标准AI基准可以通过帮助供应商和用户衡量AI安全性并鼓励资源和专业提供商的生态系统来帮助社区负责任地发展，以提供有力的工具，并提供了专注于改善AI安全性的生态系统。 </p>; <p>;同时，如果没有社区的参与，就不可能开发有效和可信赖的成熟AI安全基准。这项工作将需要研究人员和工程师聚集在一起，为安全测试技术提供创新但实际的改进，从而使测试更加严格，更高效。同样，公司将需要聚集在一起，提供测试数据，工程支持和财务支持。人工智能安全的某些方面可能是主观的，建立由广泛共识支持的可信赖的基准将需要纳入多种观点，包括公共倡导者，政策制定者，学者，工程师，工程师，数据工作者，商业领袖和企业家的观点。 </p>; <p>;自然语言处理（NLP）的目标是开发可以理解和生成自然语言的计算模型。通过捕获基于文本的自然语言的统计模式和结构，语言模型可以预测和生成一致且有意义的单词序列。通过越来越多的成功<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1706.03762">;变压器</a>;模型体系结构以及大量文本培训（具有成比例的计算和模型尺寸）来实现，大型语言模型（LLM）在NLP任务中表现出了很大的成功。 </p>; <a name='more'>; </a>; <p>;但是，对口语进行建模仍然是一个具有挑战性的领域。通常以<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/wiki/speech_recognition">;自动语音识别">;自动语音识别</a>;（asr）的级联/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/natural-language_understanding">; natural语言理解</a>;（nlu），响应生成和<a href="https://simple.wikipedia.org/wikipedia.org/wikipedia.org/wiki/wiki/wiki/wiki/wiki/text_speech">;文本-to-Speech </a>;（TTS）系统。但是，迄今为止，很少有能力的端到端系统用于进行口语建模：即，可以采用语音输入并将其作为语音输出生成其延续的单个模型。 </p>; <p>;今天，我们提出了一种用于口语建模的新方法，称为Spectron，发表在“ <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.15255”>;使用Spectrograms使用Spectrogram的口语回答和语音延续 - 能力的LLM </a>;。” Spectron是第一个经过端对端训练的口语模型，可以直接处理频谱图作为输入和输出，而不是学习离散的语音表示。仅使用预先训练的文本语言模型，可以进行微调以生成高质量的语义准确的口语。此外，所提出的模型在保持原始LLM知识的直接初始化后改善，如口语<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/wiki/wiki/question_answering">;问题答案</a>;数据集</a>; datasets。</a>; /p>; <p>;我们表明，预先训练的语音编码器和语言模型解码器可以在不牺牲代表性忠诚的情况下端到端培训和最先进的表现。关键是一个新颖的端到端训练目标，该目标以共同的方式隐含地监督语音识别，文本延续和有条件的语音综合。新的频谱回归损耗还监督模型，以匹配频谱图的高阶导数。这些衍生物一次表达从多个帧汇总的信息。因此，他们表达有关信号形状的丰富，较长的信息。我们的整体方案总结在下图中：</p>; cross-entropy </a >;损失（用于语音识别和笔录的延续）和新颖的重建损失（用于语音延续）。在推论期间，提供了口语发音提示，该提示已编码然后解码以提供文本和语音连续性。 </p>; <div style =“ line-height：40％;”>; <br />; </>; </>; “ https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.01037">; conformer </a>;编码器在<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.0101037">;大规模数据</a>; （12m小时）。它将源语音的频谱图作为输入，生成一个包含语言和声学信息的隐藏表示形式。首先使用卷积层对输入频谱图进行了次采样，然后通过一系列构象构块进行处理。每个构型块由一个馈送层，一个自发注意层，卷积层和第二个进料层组成。输出通过投影层将隐藏表示形式与语言模型的嵌入维度匹配。 </p>; <div style =“ line-height：40％;”>; <br />; </>; </>;分别以<a href="https://ai.google/static/documents/palm2techreport.pdf">; Palm 2 </a>;的方式进行了延续和提问任务。该模型作为前缀接收提示的编码功能。请注意，这是语音编码器和LM解码器之间的唯一连接；即，编码器和解码器之间没有跨注意。与大多数口语模型不同，在培训期间，解码器被教师善于预测文本转录，文本延续和语音嵌入。为了将语音嵌入到频谱图中和从频谱图中，我们介绍了轻量级模块前和网络后的模块。 </p>; <p>;通过具有相同的体系结构解码中间文本和频谱图，我们获得了两个好处。首先，LM在文本域中的预训练允许在综合语音之前延续文本域中的提示。其次，预测的文本用作中间推理，增强了综合语音的质量，类似于使用中间人时基于文本的语言模型的改进<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.00114 ">; scratchpads <>; /a>;或<a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2022/05/language-models-perform-reasoning-reasoning-via.html">; chain of-of-of-of-of-of-of-of-of-of-thought thought </a>;（cot）推理。 </p>; <div style =“ line-height：40％;”>; <br />; </>; </>; </>;我们采用多层<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/perceptron">; perceptron </a>;“ pre-net”来将地面真实频谱演讲连续性投射到语言模型维度上。此预内网将频谱图输入压缩到较低的维度，从而产生有助于解码过程的瓶颈。这种瓶颈机制可防止模型在解码过程中重复生成相同的预测。为了将LM输出从语言模型维度投射到频谱图维度，该模型采用了“后网”，这也是多层感知器。前网和后的均是两层多层感知器。 </p>; </tbody>;</ table>; <br />; <h2>;Performance</h2>; <p>; To empirically evaluate the performance of the proposed approach, we conducted experiments on the<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1912.07875">; Libri-Light dataset</a>;. Libri-Light is a 60k hour English dataset consisting of unlabelled speech readings from LibriVox audiobooks. We utilized a frozen neural vocoder called <a href="https://research.google/pubs/pub51736/">;WaveFit</a>; to convert the predicted spectrograms into raw audio. We experiment with two tasks, speech continuation and spoken question answering (QA). Speech continuation quality is tested on the LibriSpeech test set. Spoken QA is tested on the Spoken WebQuestions datasets and a new test set named LLama questions, which we created. For all experiments, we use a 3 second audio prompt as input. We compare our method against existing spoken language models: <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.03143">;AudioLM</a>;, <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2102.01192">;GSLM</a>;, <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.13009">;TWIST</a>; and <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.11000">;SpeechGPT</a>;. For the speech continuation task, we use the 350M parameter version of LM and the 1B version for the spoken QA task. </p>; <p>; For the speech continuation task, we evaluate our method using three metrics. The first is <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perplexity">;log-perplexity</a>;, which uses an LM to evaluate the cohesion and semantic quality of the generated speech. The second is <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean_opinion_score">;mean opinion score</a>; (MOS), which measures how natural the speech sounds to human evaluators. The third, speaker similarity, uses a speaker encoder to measure how similar the speaker in the output is to the speaker in the input. Performance in all 3 metrics can be seen in the following graphs. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>; <tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi_o_DUlZ-28VmNk20zvWBWC5FNl3GMVeigztDAtB4TR5voCdX3zzuCF-6W6DDrMVGZ2szVhyphenhyphendPz1DHvjBrALQXCMkVzuM81oBck4Wb3N1VH1ndDReAPsfbQv5x7msOD3wMiHeZM-_AcN2ekgSI_G9sF5_u0lrLKc-xxSWc2d9qi6Ubt5cutgQfpIt8uKGr/s1200/image5 .png" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="742" data-original-width="1200" height="396" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi_o_DUlZ-28VmNk20zvWBWC5FNl3GMVeigztDAtB4TR5voCdX3zzuCF-6W6DDrMVGZ2szVhyphenhyphendPz1DHvjBrALQXCMkVzuM81oBck4Wb3N1VH1ndDReAPsfbQv5x7msOD3wMiHeZM-_AcN2ekgSI_G9sF5_u0lrLKc-xxSWc2d9qi6Ubt5cutgQfpIt8uKGr/w640-h396/image5.png" width="640" />;</a>;</ td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;<em style="text-align: left;">;Log-perplexity for completions of LibriSpeech utterances given a 3-second prompt. Lower is better.</em>;</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com /img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgjUncRH61ZdMzRhsx9NEXoY0P0jIMkaXhycc9AjB2I0pr8bEWxGNaY0KEF4UG0dm6ZVjRT3_aXlNKny3mmjoVgPveK4rskOgU5sApzqzIXixabv7kMeZNMxUpxs_RDqSsnij-HILgUzVZT39hoBDimw9Ecnd2lMq2ylyRCVtcU_owo8jx9ndVrLUHbGhNT/s1200/image4.png" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="742" data-original-width="1200" height="396" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgjUncRH61ZdMzRhsx9NEXoY0P0jIMkaXhycc9AjB2I0pr8bEWxGNaY0KEF4UG0dm6ZVjRT3_aXlNKny3mmjoVgPveK4rskOgU5sApzqzIXixabv7kMeZNMxUpxs_RDqSsnij-HILgUzVZT39hoBDimw9Ecnd2lMq2ylyRCVtcU_owo8jx9ndVrLUHbGhNT/w640-h396/image4.png" width="640" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;<em style="text-align: left;">; Speaker similarity between the prompt speech and the generated speech using the speaker encoder. Higher is better.</em>;</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjBdPk77at7a-tSVl1cgPTlMsj4tnV391evuyYPzMXxeviG48kljCNy828jCQ5eVdOcB7ML4FHduIHCuDweZwJiv2USbNqi1EXinzyiwQYM3Sxio3g-61xTBvtb9rVt_Y4Cvns-vl3V-4Gvn1RTpBquX3a6W_NNu6u-1DrK_GT5uGXOvP0WivyO7FF2-WTf/s1200/image3.png" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="742" data-original-width="1200" height="396" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjBdPk77at7a-tSVl1cgPTlMsj4tnV391evuyYPzMXxeviG48kljCNy828jCQ5eVdOcB7ML4FHduIHCuDweZwJiv2USbNqi1EXinzyiwQYM3Sxio3g-61xTBvtb9rVt_Y4Cvns-vl3V-4Gvn1RTpBquX3a6W_NNu6u-1DrK_GT5uGXOvP0WivyO7FF2-WTf/w640-h396/image3.png" width="640" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;<em style="text-align: left;">;MOS given by human users on speech naturalness. Raters rate 5-scale subjective mean opinion score (MOS) ranging between 0 - 5 in naturalness given a speech utterance. Higher is better.</em>;</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; As can be seen in the first graph, our method significantly outperforms GSLM and TWIST on the log-perplexity metric, and does slightly better than state-of-the-art methods AudioLM and SpeechGPT. In terms of MOS, Spectron exceeds the performance of all the other methods except for AudioLM. In terms of speaker similarity, our method outperforms all other methods. </p>; <p>; To evaluate the ability of the models to perform question answering, we use two spoken question answering datasets. The first is the LLama Questions dataset, which uses general knowledge questions in different domains generated using the LLama2 70B LLM. The second dataset is the <a href="https://huggingface.co/datasets/web_questions">;WebQuestions</a>; dataset which is a general question answering dataset. For evaluation we use only questions that fit into the 3 second prompt length. To compute accuracy, answers are transcribed and compared to the ground truth answers in text form. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>; <tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi60RnurzgglmP14m9BIScZH4BmupewxydVJ5GZMKclwDgyGc3-zZdj8CK7WXmGR_-pwno1Aql0N_u0ocmftoAlTCJY0H-1cYU8YTpxZu5sdIdmG-wZAc-hIwlAbCEVDPgGz4J4a1VMcXWctbjcfCTxsDSZPD69eGfBeGyAxvyYtUX0fE2dhdT5zb71gsJ0/s1200 /image1.png" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="742" data-original-width="1200" height=" 396" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi60RnurzgglmP14m9BIScZH4BmupewxydVJ5GZMKclwDgyGc3-zZdj8CK7WXmGR_-pwno1Aql0N_u0ocmftoAlTCJY0H-1cYU8YTpxZu5sdIdmG-wZAc-hIwlAbCEVDPgGz4J4a1VMcXWctbjcfCTxsDSZPD69eGfBeGyAxvyYtUX0fE2dhdT5zb71gsJ0/w640-h396/image1.png" width="640" />;</ a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;<em style="text-align: left;">;Accuracy for Question Answering on the LLama Questions and Spoken WebQuestions datasets. Accuracy is computed using the ASR transcripts of spoken answers.</em>;</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; First, we observe that all methods have more difficulty answering questions from the Spoken WebQuestions dataset than from the LLama questions dataset. Second, we observe that methods centered around spoken language modeling such as GSLM, AudioLM and TWIST have a completion-centric behavior rather than direct question answering which hindered their ability to perform QA. On the LLama questions dataset our method outperforms all other methods, while SpeechGPT is very close in performance. On the Spoken WebQuestions dataset, our method outperforms all other methods except for SpeechGPT, which does marginally better. </p>; <br />; <h2>;Acknowledgements</h2>; <p>;<i>;This project was conceived and initiated by Michelle Tadmor Ramanovich with additional significant contributions from</i>;<em>; Eliya Nachmani, Alon Levkovitch, Roy Hirsch (<a href="https://verily.com/">;Verily</a>;), Julian Salazar, Chulayutsh Asawaroengchai, Soroosh Mariooryad, Ehud Rivlin (<a href="https://verily.com/">;Verily</a>;) and RJ Skerry-Ryan. scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Machine Learning">;</category>;<title type="text">;Looking back at wildfire research in 2023</stitle>;<content type="html">;<span class="byline-author">;Posted by Yi-Fan Chen, Software Engineer, and Carla Bromberg, Program Lead, Google Research</span>; <img src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgCepSXB1QxIgipeUbH1YGd8N3TkVoT1tAgxG0fC0PPREhbsygTQ4i58OVw6-Dt_lagwgswT0jtxUorsVmtyO9UgPEDezJHz_QiKvbJlgYF8Db8W-68KFdyZsq_uvM7YuZo9BRo__NC4BNxD6nHZpzsimeNOaV3X8dh9aliqbAbk8ycXb25s5NfLTfNe42_/s600/WildfireModeling.gif" style="display: none;" />; <p>;Wildfires are becoming larger and affecting more and more communities around the world, often resulting in large-scale devastation. Just this year, communities have experienced catastrophic wildfires in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Greece_wildfires">;Greece</a>;, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Hawaii_wildfires#Maui">;Maui</a>;, and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Canadian_wildfires">;Canada</a>; to name a few. While the underlying causes leading to such an increase are complex — including changing climate patterns, forest management practices, land use development policies and many more — it is clear that the advancement of technologies can help to address the new challenges.</p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <p>;At Google Research, we've been investing in a number of <a href="https://research.google/teams/climate-and-sustainability/">;climate adaptation</a>; efforts, including the application of machine learning (ML) to aid in wildfire prevention and provide information to people during these events. For example, to help map fire boundaries, our wildfire boundary <a href="https://blog.research.google/2023/02/real-time-tracking-of-wildfire.html">;tracker</a>; uses ML models and satellite imagery to map large fires in near real-time with updates every 15 minutes. To advance our various research efforts, we are partnering with wildfire experts and government agencies around the world.</p>; <p>;Today we are excited to share more about our ongoing collaboration with the <a href="https://www.fs.usda.gov/">;US Forest Service</a>; (USFS) to advance fire modeling tools and fire spread prediction algorithms. Starting from the newly developed USFS wildfire behavior model, we use ML to significantly reduce computation times, thus enabling the model to be employed in near real time. This new model is also capable of incorporating localized fuel characteristics, such as fuel type and distribution, in its predictions. Finally, we describe an early version of our new high-fidelity 3D fire spread model.</p>; <br />; <h2>;Current state of the art in wildfire modeling</h2>; <p>;Today's most widely used state-of-the-art fire behavior models for fire operation and training are based on the <a href="https://www.fs.usda.gov/research/treesearch/55928">;Rothermel fire model</a>; developed at the US Forest Service Fire Lab, by Rothermel et al., in the 1970s. This model considers many key factors that affect fire spread, such as the influence of wind, the slope of the terrain, the moisture level, the fuel load (eg, the density of the combustible materials in the forest), etc., and provided a good balance between computational feasibility and accuracy at the time. The Rothermel model has gained widespread use throughout the fire management community across the world.</p>; <p>;Various operational tools that employ the Rothermel model, such as <a href="https://www.frames.gov/behaveplus/home">;BEHAVE</a>;, <a href="https://www.firelab.org/project/farsite">;FARSITE</a>;, <a href="https://wfdss.usgs.gov/wfdss/pdfs/FSPro.pdf">;FSPro</a>;, and <a href="https://firelab.org/project/flammap">;FlamMap</a>;, have been developed and improved over the years. These tools and the underlying model are used mainly in three important ways: (1) for training firefighters and fire managers to develop their insights and intuitions on fire behavior, (2) for fire behavior analysts to predict the development of a fire during a fire operation and to generate guidance for situation awareness and resource allocation planning, and (3) for analyzing forest management options intended to mitigate fire hazards across large landscapes.  These models are the foundation of fire operation safety and efficiency today.</p>; <p>; However, there are limitations on these state-of-the art models, mostly associated with the simplification of the underlying physical processes (which was necessary when these models were created). By simplifying the physics to produce steady state predictions, the required inputs for fuel sources and weather became practical but also more abstract compared to measurable quantities.  As a result, these models are typically “adjusted” and “tweaked” by experienced fire behavior analysts so they work more accurately in certain situations and to compensate for uncertainties and unknowable environmental characteristics. Yet these expert adjustments mean that many of the calculations are not repeatable. </p>; <p>;To overcome these limitations, USFS researchers have been working on a new model to drastically improve the physical fidelity of fire behavior prediction. This effort represents the first major shift in fire modeling in the past 50 years. While the new model <a href="https://ebooks.publish.csiro.au/content/wildland-fire-behaviour">;continues to improve in capturing fire behavior</a>;, the computational cost and inference time makes it impractical to be deployed in the field or for applications with near real-time requirements. In a realistic scenario, to make this model useful and practical in training and operations, a speed up of at least 1000x would be needed.</p>; <br />; <h2>;Machine learning acceleration</h2>; <p>;In partnership with the USFS, we have undertaken a program to apply ML to decrease computation times for complex fire models. Researchers knew that many complex inputs and features could be characterized using a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_learning">;deep neural network</a>;, and if successful, the trained model would lower the computational cost and latency of evaluating new scenarios. Deep learning is a branch of machine learning that uses neural networks with multiple hidden layers of nodes that do not directly correspond to actual observations. The model's hidden layers allow a rich representation of extremely complex systems — an ideal technique for modeling wildfire spread.</p>; <p>; We used the USFS physics-based, numerical prediction models to generate many simulations of wildfire behavior and then used these simulated examples to train the deep learning model on the inputs and features to best capture the system behavior accurately. We found that the deep learning model can perform at a much lower computational cost compared to the original and is able to address behaviors resulting from fine-scale processes. In some cases, computation time for capturing the fine-scale features described above and providing a fire spread estimate was 100,000 times faster than running the physics-based numerical models. </p>; <p>;This project has continued to make great progress since the first report at <a href="https://www.adai.pt/newevent/event/home/index.php?target=home&event =4&defLang=2">;ICFFR</a>; in December 2022. The joint Google–USFS <a href="http://books.uc.pt/chapter?chapter=978989262298921">;presentation at ICFFR 2022</ a>; and the <a href="https://www.firelab.org/project/deep-learning-high-resolution-wildfire-modeling">;USFS Fire Lab's project page</a>; provides a glimpse into the ongoing work朝这个方向。 Our team has expanded the dataset used for training by an order of magnitude, from 40M up to 550M training examples. Additionally, we have delivered a prototype ML model that our USFS Fire Lab partner is integrating into a training app that is currently being developed for release in 2024.</p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjdwdwG4NlOjrJlRs25p5yGRUdNDErx7I9aZYLVgoPhrlyiOOx6x8toan0DKoBm2-SG2JfWkZsOluT7g_BYJpDYCTqMRu3cUHqQtyeE-Hgli5j9J3ap2Sg9SrjEfOMXj_CYhbi66iIFwSJjzkii0kJv3VV5V01jbIYFQP-DWjBc9RJKKEoJZPpIZKKYO2TJ/s1999/image2.jpg" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="1125" data-original-width="1999" height="360" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjdwdwG4NlOjrJlRs25p5yGRUdNDErx7I9aZYLVgoPhrlyiOOx6x8toan0DKoBm2-SG2JfWkZsOluT7g_BYJpDYCTqMRu3cUHqQtyeE-Hgli5j9J3ap2Sg9SrjEfOMXj_CYhbi66iIFwSJjzkii0kJv3VV5V01jbIYFQP-DWjBc9RJKKEoJZPpIZKKYO2TJ/w640-h360/image2.jpg" width="640" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;<span style="text-align: left;">;Google researchers visiting the USFS Fire Lab in Missoula, MT, stopping by </span>;<a href="https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident-information/mtfha-big-knife" style="text-align: left;">;Big Knife Fire</a>;<span style="text-align: left;">; Operation Command Center.</span>;</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <h2>;Fine-grained fuel representation</h2>; <p>;Besides training, another key use-case of the new model is for operational fire prediction. To fully leverage the advantages of the new model's capability to capture the detailed fire behavior changes from small-scale differences in fuel structures, high resolution fuel mapping and representation are needed. To this end, we are currently working on the integration of high resolution satellite imagery and geo information into ML models to allow fuel specific mapping at-scale. Some of the preliminary results will be presented at the upcoming <a href="https://afefirecongress.org/schedule/">;10th International Fire Ecology and Management Congress</a>; in November 2023.</p>; <br />; <h2>;Future work</h2>; <p>; Beyond the collaboration on the new fire spread model, there are many important and challenging problems that can help fire management and safety. Many such problems require even more accurate fire models that fully consider 3D flow interactions and fluid dynamics, thermodynamics and combustion physics. Such detailed calculations usually require high-performance computers (HPCs) or supercomputers. </p>; <p>; These models can be used for research and longer-term planning purposes to develop insights on extreme fire development scenarios, build ML classification models, or establish a meaningful “danger index” using the simulated results. These high-fidelity simulations can also be used to supplement physical experiments that are used in expanding the operational models mentioned above. </p>; <p>;In this direction, Google research has also <a href="https://www.publish.csiro.au/WF/WF22225">;developed a high-fidelity large-scale 3D fire simulator</a>; that can be run on Google TPUs. In the near future, there is a plan to further leverage this new capability to augment the experiments, and to generate data to build insights on the development of extreme fires and use the data to design a fire-danger classifier and fire-danger index protocol.</p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi4SgYHTgu7Uv6WNEJsEJCuFWKolnL13g9BxK2cDuMq7-SRM4dIUK9LbNxy3v0VyY4dU87T_NnehBz4iXCfHCWwoOU6V8-15P55Oi6FvT5BvcLgR_vzYB1xMPWUtj3AiwSsoPZY-9K5i9IwIADDAIjG7hzZZZZ00n7N2jVnjlp65ePQDsJdNIuX6avw8kD_/s480/image1.gif" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="270" data-original-width="480" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEi4SgYHTgu7Uv6WNEJsEJCuFWKolnL13g9BxK2cDuMq7-SRM4dIUK9LbNxy3v0VyY4dU87T_NnehBz4iXCfHCWwoOU6V8-15P55Oi6FvT5BvcLgR_vzYB1xMPWUtj3AiwSsoPZY-9K5i9IwIADDAIjG7hzZZZZ00n7N2jVnjlp65ePQDsJdNIuX6avw8kD_/s16000/image1.gif" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;<span style="text-align: left;">;An example of 3D high-fidelity simulation. This is a controlled burn field experiment (</span>;<a href="https://www.fireweather.org/fireflux2" style="text-align: left;">;FireFlux II</a>;<span style="text-align: left;">;) simulated using </span>;<a href="https://www.publish.csiro.au/WF/WF22225">;Google's high fidelity fire simulator</a>;<span style="text-align: left;">;.</span>;</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <h2>;Acknowledgements</h2>; <p>;<i>;We thank Mark Finney, Jason Forthofer, William Chatham and Issac Grenfell from US Forest Service Missoula Fire Science Laboratory and our colleagues John Burge, Lily Hu, Qing Wang, Cenk Gazen, Matthias Ihme, Vivian Yang, Fei Sha and John Anderson for core contributions and useful discussions. We also thank Tyler Russell for his assistance with program management and coordination.</i>;</p>;</content>;<link href="http://blog.research.google/feeds/7317378303167958176/comments/default" scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="NLP">;</category>;<category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Search">;</category>;<title type="text">;Grammar checking at Google Search scale</stitle>;<content type="html">;<span class="byline-author">;Posted by Eric Malmi, Senior Research Scientist, and Jakub Adamek, Senior Software Engineer, Google, Bard Team </span>; <img src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhW7pWsW1-E7U1LH1bxmjBL_2W5fS6uN2iRb2cNPBks57ubvFNJj-SjE2Zk1lFqndKWBVAeO3g3MLeJ96QUIUNJDyLTcWjeO835NT6HfJMYQBEdGqL-X_sxQ1yxMy16a0OcOLb6gSz2lqM6VofToVtN_s_F_wGB41AZwlj146y7ZXQ4PFsdywX10QO54MJ4/s320/HeroGC.jpg" style="display: none;" />; <p>; Many people with questions about grammar turn to Google Search for guidance. While existing features, such as “Did you mean”, already handle simple typo corrections, more complex grammatical error correction (GEC) is beyond their scope. What makes the development of new Google Search features challenging is that they must have high precision and recall while outputting results <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2009/06/speed-matters.html">;quickly< /a>;. </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <p>; The conventional approach to GEC is to treat it as a <a href="https://workspace.google.com/blog/ai-and-machine-learning/using-neural-machine-translation-to-correct-grammatical-in-google-docs">;translation problem</a>; and use autoregressive <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2017/08/transformer-novel-neural-network.html">;Transformer</a>; models to decode the response token-by-token, conditioning on the previously generated tokens. However, although Transformer models have proven to be effective at GEC, they aren't particularly efficient because the generation cannot be parallelized due to <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autoregressive_model">;autoregressive</a>; decoding. Often, only a few modifications are needed to make the input text grammatically correct, so another possible solution is to treat GEC as a <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.07043">;text editing</a>;问题。 If we could run the autoregressive decoder only to generate the modifications, that would substantially decrease the latency of the GEC model. </p>; <p>; To this end, in “<a href="https://aclanthology.org/2022.findings-emnlp.156/">;EdiT5: Semi-Autoregressive Text-Editing with T5 Warm-Start</a>;”, published at Findings of <a href="https://2022.emnlp.org/" target="_blank">;EMNLP 2022</a>;, we describe a novel text-editing model that is based on the <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1910.10683">;T5</a>; Transformer encoder-decoder architecture. EdiT5 powers the new Google Search <a href="https://support.google.com/websearch/answer/13420782">;grammar check feature</a>; that allows you to check if a phrase or sentence is grammatically correct and provides corrections when needed. Grammar check shows up when the phrase "grammar check" is included in a search query, and if the underlying model is confident about the correction. Additionally, it shows up for some queries that don't contain the “grammar check” phrase when Search understands that is the likely intent. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>; <tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEh-BAXZ3wH-FcJmFoKvppChwvfZay7xH5bhiYmKQocV47sCb3IMfwEec1OpBWY3b1fd2rnA4Vhy4EqOCZiAR4Xpv6xPok9yC-ZqLogbER2lcmaje1NfBCoPAtdW7rEPG22PtNn4dVuYtYH61D9fnx7kudLZilxzUbi01ePhirqtTwMu6g9trhFFuLCDUCgP/s1412/image4.png " style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="546" data-original-width="1412" src="https:// blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEh-BAXZ3wH-FcJmFoKvppChwvfZay7xH5bhiYmKQocV47sCb3IMfwEec1OpBWY3b1fd2rnA4Vhy4EqOCZiAR4Xpv6xPok9yC-ZqLogbER2lcmaje1NfBCoPAtdW7rEPG22PtNn4dVuYtYH61D9fnx7kudLZilxzUbi01ePhirqtTwMu6g9trhFFuLCDUCgP/s16000/image4.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr- caption" style="text-align: center;">;</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br / >; </div>; <h2>;Model architecture</h2>; <p>; For low-latency applications at Google, Transformer models are typically run on <a href="https://cloud.google.com/tpu/docs/ intro-to-tpu">;TPUs</a>;. Due to their fast matrix multiplication units (MMUs), these devices are optimized for performing large matrix multiplications quickly, for example running a Transformer encoder on hundreds of tokens in only a few milliseconds. In contrast, Transformer decoding makes poor use of a TPU's capabilities, because it forces it to process only one token at a time. This makes autoregressive decoding the most time-consuming part of a translation-based GEC model. </p>; <p>; In the EdiT5 approach, we reduce the number of decoding steps by treating GEC as a text editing problem. The EdiT5 text-editing model is based on the <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1910.10683">;T5</a>; Transformer encoder-decoder architecture with a few crucial modifications. Given an input with grammatical errors, the EdiT5 model uses an encoder to determine which input tokens to keep or delete. The kept input tokens form a draft output, which is optionally reordered using a non-autoregressive <a href="https://proceedings.neurips.cc/paper_files/paper/2015/file/29921001f2f04bd3baee84a12e98098f-Paper.pdf">;pointer network </a>;。 Finally, a decoder outputs the tokens that are missing from the draft, and uses a pointing mechanism to indicate where each new token should be placed to generate a grammatically correct output. The decoder is only run to produce tokens that were missing in the draft, and as a result, runs for much fewer steps than would be needed in the translation approach to GEC. </p>; <p>;To further decrease the decoder latency, we reduce the decoder down to a single layer, and we compensate by increasing the size of the encoder. Overall, this decreases latency significantly because the extra work in the encoder is efficiently parallelized.</p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEg2_MGEcdadlbXM1zMBQzROuRbYyqmcdhcytlnwdHeIJ_M0wrtioaRixoDOxMlE3acuMZRf4KB_T5TgzUCfBBmz3eeEMnnAKHZkvFmMzFnNu_2UAI1l3jhOp2dyQyOxElXwt7iEjun_gd77uk1TMiaBLlMfxEOxcFo8W48fdD9WqbYNvUZECUEd-LHTk1-R/s1878/image2.png" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="1332" data-original-width="1878" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEg2_MGEcdadlbXM1zMBQzROuRbYyqmcdhcytlnwdHeIJ_M0wrtioaRixoDOxMlE3acuMZRf4KB_T5TgzUCfBBmz3eeEMnnAKHZkvFmMzFnNu_2UAI1l3jhOp2dyQyOxElXwt7iEjun_gd77uk1TMiaBLlMfxEOxcFo8W48fdD9WqbYNvUZECUEd-LHTk1-R/s16000/image2.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;Given an input with grammatical errors (“Guess when was I borned”), the EdiT5 model uses an encoder to determine which input tokens to keep (K) or delete (D), a pointer network (pointer) to reorder kept tokens, and a decoder to insert any new tokens that are needed to generate a grammatically correct output.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; We applied the EdiT5 model to the <a href="https://aclanthology.org/W19-4406/">;public BEA grammatical error correction benchmark</a>;, comparing different model sizes. The experimental results show that an EdiT5 large model with 391M parameters yields a higher <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-score">;F0.5 score</a>;, which measures the accuracy of the corrections, while delivering a 9x speedup compared to a T5 base model with 248M parameters. The mean latency of the EdiT5 model was merely 4.1 milliseconds. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>; <tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjQys5EavCOAEs0dy3M8r5Ar-9v7n5qtFkek1VSfeGBXH1pQHNv6Ebem3vDedO60BlNcp3HLGqYtsT4v4Evz2u2ksTgFfQcQIqd87NPTxVzYVyzvA85Vg_jO8a18KrMT2hOQQA5hg2frOJx2L7S5SM88VBCJzd13ClrSzHnl5xg29TMMpvqA4Yl-d98vTc1/s1987/image1.jpeg" style ="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="1311" data-original-width="1987" src="https://blogger. googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjQys5EavCOAEs0dy3M8r5Ar-9v7n5qtFkek1VSfeGBXH1pQHNv6Ebem3vDedO60BlNcp3HLGqYtsT4v4Evz2u2ksTgFfQcQIqd87NPTxVzYVyzvA85Vg_jO8a18KrMT2hOQQA5hg2frOJx2L7S5SM88VBCJzd13ClrSzHnl5xg29TMMpvqA4Yl-d98vTc1/s16000/image1.jpeg" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style= "text-align: center;">;Performance of the T5 and EdiT5 models of various sizes on the public BEA GEC benchmark plotted against mean latency. Compared to T5, EdiT5 offers a better latency-F0.5 trade-off. Note that the x axis is logarithmic.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Improved training data with large language models</h2>; <p>; Our <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2106.03830">;earlier research</a>;, as well as the results above, show that model size plays a crucial role in generating accurate grammatical corrections. To combine the advantages of large language models (LLMs) and the low latency of EdiT5, we leverage a technique called <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1503.02531">;hard distillation</a>;. First, we train a teacher LLM using similar datasets used for the <a href="https://ai.googleblog.com/2021/10/grammar-correction-as-you-type-on-pixel.html">;Gboard grammar model</a>;. The teacher model is then used to generate training data for the student EdiT5 model. </p>; <p>; Training sets for grammar models consist of <em>;ungrammatical source / grammatical target</em>; sentence pairs. Some of the training sets have noisy targets that contain grammatical errors, unnecessary paraphrasing, or unwanted artifacts. Therefore, we generate new pseudo-targets with the teacher model to get cleaner and more consistent training data. Then, we re-train the teacher model with the pseudo-targets using a technique called <em>;<a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/1909.13788">;self-training</a>;</em>; 。 Finally, we found that when the source sentence contains many errors, the teacher sometimes corrects only part of the errors. Thus, we can further improve the quality of the pseudo-targets by feeding them to the teacher LLM for a second time, a technique called <em>;<a href="https://aclanthology.org/D19-1435/">;iterative refinement</a>;</em>;. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>; <tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgJzgocbj86SS8moSqWrxIKz8E3CxZn712Di2CY7pwgXZ355Z4qUnDBxuEc91AU9jAdKwq4tvyaCzIqKfcJzThrjkka5q1LwXGWNa1xPi5AU7RpJDq-XmoNHs386B2bJqKDDnN8_l1mvLCSShlGjb66RWy25Z_1QXwMDpHDgsPON7r0pUqYdXZLPsx06hOC/s1089/image3.png" style=" margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="984" data-original-width="1089" src="https://blogger.googleusercontent. com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgJzgocbj86SS8moSqWrxIKz8E3CxZn712Di2CY7pwgXZ355Z4qUnDBxuEc91AU9jAdKwq4tvyaCzIqKfcJzThrjkka5q1LwXGWNa1xPi5AU7RpJDq-XmoNHs386B2bJqKDDnN8_l1mvLCSShlGjb66RWy25Z_1QXwMDpHDgsPON7r0pUqYdXZLPsx06hOC/s16000/image3.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align : center;">;Steps for training a large teacher model for grammatical error correction (GEC). Self-training and iterative refinement remove unnecessary paraphrasing, artifacts, and grammatical errors appearing in the original targets.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Putting it all together</h2>; <p>; Using the improved GEC data, we train two EdiT5-based models: a grammatical error correction model, and a grammaticality分类器。 When the grammar check feature is used, we run the query first through the correction model, and then we check if the output is indeed correct with the classifier model. Only then do we surface the correction to the user. </p>; <p>; The reason to have a separate classifier model is to more easily trade off between precision and recall. Additionally, for ambiguous or nonsensical queries to the model where the best correction is unclear, the classifier reduces the risk of serving erroneous or confusing corrections. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Conclusion</h2>; <p>; We have developed an efficient grammar correction model based on the state-of-the-art EdiT5 model architecture. This model allows users to check for the grammaticality of their queries in Google Search by including the “grammar check” phrase in the query. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Acknowledgements</h2>; <p>; <em>;We gratefully acknowledge the key contributions of the other team members, including Akash R, Aliaksei Severyn, Harsh Shah, Jonathan Mallinson, Mithun Kumar SR, Samer Hassan, Sebastian Krause, and Shikhar Thakur. We'd also like to thank Felix Stahlberg, Shankar Kumar, and Simon Tong for helpful discussions and pointers.</em>; </p>;</content>;<link scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="distributed systems">;</category>;<category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Publications">;</category>;<category scheme="http://www.blogger.com/atom/ns#" term="Research">;</category>;<title type="text">;Answering billions of reporting queries each day with low latency</stitle>;<content type="html">;<span class="byline-author">;Posted by Jagan Sankaranarayanan, Senior Staff Software Engineer, and Indrajit Roy, Head of Napa Product, Google</span>; <img src="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjIZSvPVFwZPeTv8ivB-lHMGfoLkP-fDBuAy9GEklUVNBPPoqOXRfme5Psui7DbKssImVjFHtxoygKhFBvgpAG_C5852ocu9i7AOfWPeC1mSlaim8jfqsV55wZIULDUPk7WhxW1OISfL_CjZswN3CcZN7GJgVLBdepic8lfYAUCT0rAlXGGbnf-WuA6mRc6/s320/hero.jpg" style="display: none;" />; <p>; <a href="https://ads.google.com/home/">;Google Ads</a>; infrastructure runs on an internal data warehouse called <a href="https://research.google/pubs/pub50617/">;Napa</a>;. Billions of reporting queries, which power critical dashboards used by advertising clients to measure campaign performance, run on tables stored in Napa. These tables contain records of ads performance that are keyed using particular customers and the campaign identifiers with which they are associated. Keys are tokens that are used both to associate an ads record with a particular client and campaign (eg, customer_id, campaign_id) and for efficient retrieval. A record contains dozens of keys, so clients use reporting queries to specify keys needed to filter the data to understand ads performance (eg, by region, device and metrics such as clicks, etc.). What makes this problem challenging is that the data is <em>;skewed</em>; since queries require varying levels of effort to be answered and have stringent latency expectations. Specifically, some queries require the use of millions of records while others are answered with just a few. </p>; <a name='more'>;</a>; <p>; To this end, in “<a href="https://research.google/pubs/pub52572/">;Progressive Partitioning for Parallelized Query Execution in Napa</a>;”, presented at <a href="https://vldb.org/2023/">;VLDB 2023</a>;, we describe how the Napa data warehouse determines the amount of machine resources needed to answer reporting queries while meeting strict latency targets. We introduce a new progressive query partitioning algorithm that can <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parallel_computing">;parallelize</a>; query execution in the presence of complex data skews to perform consistently well in a matter of a few milliseconds. Finally, we demonstrate how Napa allows Google Ads infrastructure to serve billions of queries every day. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Query processing challenges</h2>; <p>; When a client inputs a reporting query, the main challenge is to determine how to parallelize the query effectively. Napa's parallelization technique breaks up the query into even sections that are equally distributed across available machines, which then process these in parallel to significantly reduce query latency. This is done by estimating the number of records associated with a specified key, and assigning more or less equal amounts of work to machines. However, this estimation is not perfect since reviewing all records would require the same effort as answering the query. A machine that processes significantly more than others would result in run-time skews and poor performance. Each machine also needs to have sufficient work since needless parallelism leads to underutilized infrastructure. Finally, parallelization has to be a per query decision that must be executed near-perfectly billions of times, or the query may miss the stringent latency requirements. </p>; <p>; The reporting query example below extracts the records denoted by keys (ie, <code>;customer_id</code>; and <code>;campaign_id</code>;) and then computes an aggregate (ie, <code>;SUM(cost)</code>;) from an advertiser table. In this example the number of records is too large to process on a single machine, so Napa needs to use a subsequent key (eg, <code>;adgroup_id</code>;) to further break up the collection of records so that equal distribution of work is achieved. It is important to note that at petabyte scale, the size of the data statistics needed for parallelization may be several terabytes. This means that the problem is not just about collecting enormous amounts of metadata, but also how it is managed. </p>; <span style="font-size: small;">; <pre class="prettyprint" style="margin-left: 40px; margin-right: 40px; white-space: pre-wrap;">; SELECT customer_id, campaign_id, SUM(cost) FROM advertiser_table WHERE customer_id in (1, 7, ..., x ) AND campaign_id in (10, 20, ..., y) GROUP BY customer_id, campaign_id; </pre>;</span>; <br />; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style="text-align: center;">;This reporting query example extracts records denoted by keys (ie, <code>;customer_id</code>; and <code>;campaign_id</code>;) and then computes an aggregate (ie, <code>;SUM(cost)</code>;) from an advertiser table. The query effort is determined by the keys' included in the query. Keys belonging to clients with larger campaigns may touch millions of records since the data volume directly correlates with the size of the ads campaign. This disparity of matching records based on keys reflects the <em>;skewness</em>; in data, which makes query processing a challenging problem.</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <p>; An effective solution minimizes the amount of metadata needed, focuses effort primarily on the skewed part of the key space to partition data efficiently, and works well within the allotted time. For example, if the query latency is a few hundred milliseconds, partitioning should take no longer than tens of milliseconds. Finally, a parallelization process should determine when it's reached the best possible partitioning that considers query latency expectations. To this end, we have developed a progressive partitioning algorithm that we describe later in this article. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div>; <h2>;Managing the data deluge</h2>; <p>; Tables in Napa are constantly updated, so we use <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Log-structured_merge-tree">;log-structured merge forests</a>; (LSM tree) to organize the deluge of table updates. LSM is a forest of sorted data that is temporally organized with a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B-tree">;B-tree index</a>; to support efficient key lookup queries. B-trees store summary information of the sub-trees in a hierarchical manner. Each B-tree node records the number of entries present in each subtree, which aids in the parallelization of queries. LSM allows us to <a href="https://research.google/pubs/pub50617/">;decouple</a>; the process of updating the tables from the mechanics of query serving in the sense that live queries go against a different version of the data, which is atomically updated once the next batch of ingest (called delta) has been fully prepared for querying. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>; <tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhrdgCgdHtjKomZM08fuF3qd6UWrgHHYvTgclc2iMV1UffAAMqVgsJVhGDSP4aPzPh4-kNb0hU7ZWkOAaf37k7PaTaH4k3m45fDzBaX9x0wxRSpvPADOXIDrtdTL62lFGJKzqEaDT6oz-fPxbkSxU3omqQAm8sWKmsA8SR4wHHKh6iAXbDGcU4a_WvEHsaL/s1999/image4.png" style ="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="667" data-original-width="1999" src="https://blogger. googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEhrdgCgdHtjKomZM08fuF3qd6UWrgHHYvTgclc2iMV1UffAAMqVgsJVhGDSP4aPzPh4-kNb0hU7ZWkOAaf37k7PaTaH4k3m45fDzBaX9x0wxRSpvPADOXIDrtdTL62lFGJKzqEaDT6oz-fPxbkSxU3omqQAm8sWKmsA8SR4wHHKh6iAXbDGcU4a_WvEHsaL/s16000/image4.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style= "text-align: center;">;</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>;<br />; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br />; </div >; <h2>;The partitioning problem</h2>; <p>; The data partitioning problem in our context is that we have a massively large table that is represented as an LSM tree. In the figure below, Delta 1 and 2 each have their own B-tree, and together represent 70 records. Napa breaks the records into two pieces, and assigns each piece to a different machine. The problem becomes a partitioning problem of a forest of trees and requires a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tree_traversal">;tree-traversal algorithm</a>; that can quickly split the trees into two等份。 </p>; <p>; To avoid visiting all the nodes of the tree, we introduce the concept of “good enough” partitioning. As we begin cutting and partitioning the tree into two parts, we maintain an estimate of how bad our current answer would be if we terminated the partitioning process at that instant. This is the yardstick of how close we are to the answer and is represented below by a total error margin of 40 (at this point of execution, the two pieces are expected to be between 15 and 35 records in size, the uncertainty adds up to 40）。 Each subsequent traversal step reduces the error estimate, and if the two pieces are approximately equal, it stops the partitioning process. This process continues until the desired error margin is reached, at which time we are guaranteed that the two pieces are more or less equal. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>; <tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjP1MUE1iWt7K2hKPBmTmr4LfIgARhI3a-nKsMqrcmiOejHLJbxDyKIoV-9ZF8k9_X4w9EMLikeVOufzTTmBGMqBKdH_AyrWz_UihzrZFsaNPWFXB2dD8o2RIBbXCM0shFN8a6fUMW0g830qrJx0Q3mpOLfzyQwwuYB9nilFeKt3VfKQYde9Eq5VmN8D-2i/s473/image2.png " style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="327" data-original-width="473" src="https:// blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEjP1MUE1iWt7K2hKPBmTmr4LfIgARhI3a-nKsMqrcmiOejHLJbxDyKIoV-9ZF8k9_X4w9EMLikeVOufzTTmBGMqBKdH_AyrWz_UihzrZFsaNPWFXB2dD8o2RIBbXCM0shFN8a6fUMW0g830qrJx0Q3mpOLfzyQwwuYB9nilFeKt3VfKQYde9Eq5VmN8D-2i/s16000/image2.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr- caption" style="text-align: center;">;</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br / >; </div>; <h2>;Progressive partitioning algorithm</h2>; <p>; Progressive partitioning encapsulates the notion of “good enough” in that it makes a series of moves to reduce the error estimate. The input is a set of B-trees and the goal is to cut the trees into pieces of more or less equal size. The algorithm traverses one of the trees (“drill down'' in the figure) which results in a reduction of the error estimate. The algorithm is guided by statistics that are stored with each node of the tree so that it makes an informed set of moves at each step. The challenge here is to decide how to direct effort in the best possible way so that the error bound reduces quickly in the fewest possible steps. Progressive partitioning is conducive for our use-case since the longer the algorithm runs, the more equal the pieces become. It also means that if the algorithm is stopped at any point, one still gets good partitioning, where the quality corresponds to the time spent. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>; <tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgsnglKJOlArk8nIcelyOi8Yej5O2OUWCwWzitU9PsT5h-0zWDyvpVhxrdMsbsB0ECvC_q6Y91peJ6Q2r5HjXJWsH47LSEDODJw1lm-aOt8lpMhcTyMU2LOf7m2KcykAnyRLFrpx_I95spiJi5qNecVwlJ7x_aRhSDTCON6G_o09WeN8x4BwQeXbJOBOzFW/s390/image1.png" style ="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="281" data-original-width="390" src="https://blogger. googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEgsnglKJOlArk8nIcelyOi8Yej5O2OUWCwWzitU9PsT5h-0zWDyvpVhxrdMsbsB0ECvC_q6Y91peJ6Q2r5HjXJWsH47LSEDODJw1lm-aOt8lpMhcTyMU2LOf7m2KcykAnyRLFrpx_I95spiJi5qNecVwlJ7x_aRhSDTCON6G_o09WeN8x4BwQeXbJOBOzFW/s16000/image1.png" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr-caption" style= "text-align: center;">;</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <p>; Prior work in this space uses a <a href="https://research.google/pubs/ pub52572/">;sampled table to drive the partitioning process</a>;, while the Napa approach uses a B-tree. As mentioned earlier, even just a sample from a petabyte table can be massive. A tree-based partitioning method can achieve partitioning much more efficiently than a sample-based approach, which does not use a tree organization of the sampled records. We compare progressive partitioning with an alternative approach, where sampling of the table at various resolutions (eg, 1 record sample every 250 MB and so on) aids the partitioning of the query. Experimental results show the relative speedup from progressive partitioning for queries requiring varying numbers of machines. These results demonstrate that progressive partitioning is much faster than existing approaches and the speedup increases as the size of the query increases. </p>; <table align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="tr-caption-container" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<tbody>; <tr>;<td style="text-align: center;">;<a href="https://blogger.googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEj3V3INsImX_TRgcEa2VFXMK2LtVwNyCjzqYco_QMSTQWMAIfb1D5rpF7iM4xFesoltnJI9RUQNVkuuZv7nMjDIfjzhIklmdcj1xl9B8uBMfDKLIhQ9UXgH1Vrgrf2xoNvHMrv0icZDI_PKQLo9ZA6bCzrlyvX3eayjxCH_IZjFxZ1Hy9atHm6oEUqFhZz7/s1452/image3.png" style="margin- left: auto; margin-right: auto;">;<img border="0" data-original-height="1192" data-original-width="1452" height="525" src="https://blogger .googleusercontent.com/img/b/R29vZ2xl/AVvXsEj3V3INsImX_TRgcEa2VFXMK2LtVwNyCjzqYco_QMSTQWMAIfb1D5rpF7iM4xFesoltnJI9RUQNVkuuZv7nMjDIfjzhIklmdcj1xl9B8uBMfDKLIhQ9UXgH1Vrgrf2xoNvHMrv0icZDI_PKQLo9ZA6bCzrlyvX3eayjxCH_IZjFxZ1Hy9atHm6oEUqFhZz7/w640-h525/image3.png" width="640" />;</a>;</td>;</tr>;<tr>;<td class="tr- caption" style="text-align: center;">;</td>;</tr>;</tbody>;</table>; <br />; <div style="line-height: 40%;">; <br / >; </div>; <h2>;Conclusion</h2>; <p>; Napa's progressive partitioning algorithm efficiently optimizes database queries, enabling Google Ads to serve client reporting queries billions of times each day. We note that tree traversal is a common technique that students in introductory computer science courses use, yet it also serves a critical use-case at Google. We hope that this article will inspire our readers, as it demonstrates how simple techniques and carefully designed data structures can be remarkably potent if used well. Check out the <a href="https://research.google/pubs/pub52572/">;paper</a>; and a <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dtWwUWB5JyQ">;recent talk</a>; describing Napa to learn more. </p>; <div style="line-height: 40%;">;
